title: PHPisset()Function

metadata.description: Learn about PHPisset()Function with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content: Example Check whether a variable is empty. Also check whether the variable is set/declared: "; } $b = null; // False because $b is NULL if (isset($b)) { echo "Variable 'b' is set."; } ?> Definition and Usage The isset() function checks whether a variable is set, which means that it has to be declared and is not NULL. This function returns true if the variable exists and is not NULL, otherwise it returns false. Note: If multiple variables are supplied, then this function will return true only if all of the variables are set. Tip: A variable can be unset with the unset() function. Syntax isset( variable, .... ); Parameter Values Parameter Description variable Required. Specifies the variable to check ... Optional. Another variable to check Technical Details Return Value: TRUE if variable exists and is not NULL, FALSE otherwise Return Type: Boolean PHP Version: 4.0+ PHP Changelog: PHP 5.4: Non-numeric offsets of strings now returns FALSE ★ +1

summary: This tutorial covers PHPisset()Function concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use PHPisset()Function effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of PHPisset()Function and how to apply it in your projects.
